Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Northern California Wildfire Emissions and their Atmospheric Chemical Transformations in a Highly Populated Urban Region
Award.AbstractNarration:
This RAPID research focuses on the analysis of data and samples collected during the massive wildfires burning in Napa and Sonoma Counties that began on October 10, 2017. Samples were collected from the beginning of the fires for approximately 2 weeks, through periods of major pollution episodes in the San Francisco Bay region that resulted from the interaction of biomass burning emissions with urban air pollution. The fires also burned more than 5000 homes and commercial structures, resulting in emissions from the burning of household and commercial items not typically found in emissions from more remote wildfires. This research is expected to be of great public interest due to the focus on emissions from fires that caused stinging eyes and throats, closed schools, and curtailed planned outdoor activities.

This work will quantify the contribution of emissions from these fires to the observed concentrations of organic aerosol, and document how this contribution changes with atmospheric aging. It is expected to lead to the identification of additional sources contributing to organic aerosol, both primary and secondary, that may influence the aging of the biomass burning emissions. Gas/particle partitioning data will be used to elucidate information on the formation mechanisms for secondary organic aerosol. The temporal and chemical resolution provided by the observations during plume aging will be an important tool for investigating fire emission and transformation processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The RAPID: Northern California Wildfire Emissions and their Atmospheric Chemical Transformations in a Highly Populated Urban Region project focused on the organic substances in wildfire plumes reaching a populated region and their impact on regional air quality. During the Northern California wildfires in October 2017, massive amounts of organic gases and particles were emitted from fires with complex fuel mixtures including conifers, chaparral, oak woodland and building structures, causing extreme air pollution conditions with poor visibility throughout the highly populated San Francisco Bay Area. We quickly set up speciated online measurements of volatile organic compound (VOC) with PTR-ToF-MS and semi-volatile organic compounds (SVOC) in both gas and particle phase with our Semi-Volatile Thermal desorption Aerosol Gas chromatograph (SV-TAG) at Berkeley (~50-80 km downwind of the fires) on October 10. We also collected PM2.5 on filters and analyzed them using GC×GC-ToF-EI/VUVMS (two dimensional gas chromatography with both electron impact and vacuum ultraviolet ionization coupled to high mass resolution time-of-flight mass spectrometry), and made supporting measurements such as BC, CO, CO2, and particle size distribution.

These data enable us to validate the presence and transformation of primary biomass burning (BB) marker compounds discovered in the Fire Lab controlled burning experiments, and to search for marker compounds indicating the aging process of fire emissions in the real atmosphere. On the VOC side, time series analysis shows short-lived primary BBVOCs were transformed into highly oxygenated compounds during plume transport. Aging transformed the composition of VOC in fire plumes but did not lower the reactivity because many oxidation products remained reactive. Even in the urban Berkeley area, VOCs in the fire plumes increased the total calculated OH reactivity (a number indicating the level of photochemistry) by a factor 3-4.

We quantified the concentration timelines of over 450 compounds, among which ~210 compounds were positively identified through matching with standards and/or mass spectral libraries. Combining our timelines and the emission inventory obtained in the Fire Lab studies with the information of the October 2017 wildfires, we confirmed that levoglucosan is a nonspecific tracer for all kinds of BB, while compounds like dehydroabietic acid, hydroquinone and sterol tracers can be used to infer the specific fuels burned. Through time series analysis, we also found conventional BB secondary organic aerosol (BBSOA) markers like nitrocatechols formed too fast above fires to be useful for tracing secondary chemistry and thus showed very similar temporal behavior with primary BB markers. Instead, highly oxygenated compounds like malic acid and tartaric acid may better reflect the aging processes of BBOA.

We found the mass of reduced carbon in the particle phase accounted for a higher proportion (~ 30%) of total reduced carbon in wildfire plumes than in the normal urban atmosphere (10-20%). Aging did not have a strong effect on the mass distribution between gas and particle phase, which indicates the SOA formation was counter-balanced by the net evaporation of particle phase SVOCs.

We also evaluated the contribution of wildfire emission to ambient particulate organics at Berkeley. Wildfire plumes increased the daily average particle organic carbon from below 5 µg m-3 to up to 40 µg m-3. Organic particles in wildfire plumes were mainly composed of sugars, oxygenated aromatic and nonaromatic compounds, and terpenoids. A statistical source apportionment model shows BBSOA explained over 70% of total organic carbon in the afternoons when photochemistry was strong.

Our work has improved the understanding of biomass burning marker compounds and the aging effect on biomass burning organic carbon at the molecular level. The receptor site measurement data can also be used by the public health community to inform more targeted studies on the health impacts of fire aerosols.
